column11: We were ride the boat true Negombo lagoon on month of June. It was a very nice trip. They treat nice fruits. We saw some animals. Birds, Monitors and Monkeys as well. There are nice mangrove forest. This trip will be better if your taking this Morning or evening. We recommend this to other.

Recommended by our tuk tuk driver, the boat ride was relaxed and good value, Setting out from the Dutch Canal we teavelled into the lagoon. Smooth motoring to the monkeys which I suspect have been transported here to give tourists something to ooh and aaah at. They were well fed and appeared happy even though out of their natural habitat. we also set up camp in the shallows of an island for some fruit eating. A worthwhile experience for 90 mins (no longer) and if you aren't too concerned about the contrived well trodden process which a couple of boat operators conduct. I thik our company was St Mary's tours. The pollution of the mangroves with plastic and other rubbish is concerning.
Boat ride of Negombo Lagoon wonderful experience of  tourist as well as local. on your ride you can see lot of monkeys and bird.

Was really quite nervous about this trip and only decided to go at last minute.  Have had some bad experiences in the past but was persuaded into it as it is a lagoon and was told that it would be smooth sailing.  So glad I risked it as it was fantastic to sail along the canal - so much to see.  Great to see the fish market from the water side and then to sail on into the lagoon.  Plenty of wildlife to see and so quiet - like another world.  We saw bats in the trees and made a stop at monkey island to give the monkeys left over fruit and water to drink.  A lovely trip out - well worth the small amount it cost.
The locals come here to fillet and dry their fish in the sun. It all looks very labour intensive and primitive but I'm assured very traditional. A good cultural start to our visit to Sri Lanka.
the sight of millions of fish laid out on teh beach is well worth a visit before you leave teh lagoon/negombo area, if you can stand teh smell of fish then you will have agreat time

Thoroughly enjoyed the lagoon tour today, however preferred the lagoon tour from Hikkaduwa. The tour starts on the Dutch canal, which is unfortunately dirty and smelly. Particularly interesting as you pass the fishing boats as you enter the lagoon and reach the sea. Worth doing in Negombo as there is little too do.
boat tour you can have lots of fun and you see lots of fisher boat and monkeys as well. nice experience

A "Once in a Lifetime" experience, watching the long narrow single-outrigger fishing boats with their huge billowing red-brown square sails hurling themselve up onto the sand, laden with fish.  Walk and wonder at the many thousands of salted and split fish (Tunidae) laid out on great long mats and drying in the sun.  Ignore the strong fishy smell and the scores of persistent Asian Crows, and stroll on along to the covered open-air fish market where deeper-sea fish like the delicious Butterfish or Sunfish amongst many others, are being sold and cleaned. Mounds of glistening prawns, Blue Crabs, Rock Lobsters, enough to make a Billingsgate market man gasp. One word of warning, you WILL be approached by what appear to be local beach bums offering to guide you.  They tend to be "on the beach" fishermen who go no more to sea because of ill-health or injury.  They usually speak good English and I was fortunate in that the 500 Sri Lankan Rupees (approx. 5 pounds Sterling at that time) demanded was very well earned.  So, when approached, my advice is, negociate a price beforehand, and pay after, and if the would-be guide is not to your liking for whatever reason, politely turn him down, but please, always politely with smile of thanks.. That is valid advice for any of the very many worthwhile sights in Sri Lanka

It was a wonderful experience to go on the boat ride to see the colorful birds and monkeys. Also the lagoon is beautiful and then went out to the sea. The birding guide was very informative about the different species of birds. The church in the lagoon was a unique site as well. Overall, it was a great experience to go on the boat ride on the lagoon.
lots of monkey and nice driver lol.that day were raining.little bit expensive boat ride.lots of boats as well.

The lagoon is what we fly over as we land at Bandaranayake International Airport. On the ground it did not look as charming as it did from the skies. Pleasant boat rides are available which takes you around a very laid back like lake. Worth experiencing if one has time to spare
This is very near to BIA-Colombo airport and perfect place to explore with some mangrove plants and water sports and boat tours

Fascinating spending time overlooking this beautiful lagoon. Seen from Negombo town, this is the very northern end of the lagoon where it meets the sea. Beautiful mangroves and many trawlers moored next to the road. Very atmospheric.

A very beautiful place. A boat ride would take about an hour and half. You go deep in to the lagoon. Feeding monkeys, looking at different birds and enjoying the breeze is something to relish. Must visit place in Negombo.
worth a quick trip which we arranged through our hotel by tuk-tuk but not, to our taste, worth a longer stay.

Very interesting watching the fishing boats coming and going. Negombo town is confusing to navigate but if you come out of the side roads to the south you are met with this amazing vista of placid water, colourful boats and mangroves. Negombo lagoon is huge and you are looking at the narrow section where it leads to the open sea. You get a better perspective taking off from the airport. The road follows the lagoon to the fish market where you can see fish laid out to dry in the sun.

Negombo Lagoon is 35 sq. kms and a hive of activity as fisherman are busy with their boats catching fish and shrimp. Several companies offer boat tours on the lagoon which is an estuarine lagoon. You will see many different types of birds and the fishermen at work. Also if you walk to where the inlets are located, near the fish market and on the nearby islands of Doowa and Mankuliya you will see hundreds of small fishing boats with the locals busy at work. This was one of my great experiences during my stay in Negombo. Another interesting fact is that the whole lagoon is no deeper than one meter.
